text: obviously thank you very much to David
for the kind introduction and thank you
all for the warm reception it puts me in
the mind of what one of America's
greatest thespians would have said in
response to the warm reception and that
is Sir Samuel Davis jr. would responded
such that he say it's something similar
to as you know it's really groovy when
young cats like you dig a man I was told
to keep my speech and my session to
about 20 minutes so I'm going to take my
my watch off and you know as I take this
this watch off it's interesting that it
immediately fills my mind with memories
of my my mother and as David mentioned
to you I I teach entrepreneurship
specifically entrepreneurial finance and
this this semester I am continuing my
new course that I've created titled
black business leaders on
entrepreneurship and this watch puts me
in the mind of my mother who was the
finest entrepreneur that I ever knew and
she was the finest entrepreneur I never
knew and she would be proud that I would
be speaking to you about the topic of
black entrepreneurship and we tell you a
little bit more about this watching my
mother I remember my mother was was
gravely ill and she was in the hospital
she called me into her hospital room and
she said Steve this watch has been in
our family for three generations and she
was the finest entrepreneur that I ever
knew and she said to me she said you're
the oldest of my children and she said I
like to give you the chance to buy this
watch from me
[Laughter]
what a more serious note it's truly an
honor to have been invited here today to
talk to you about the importance of
entrepreneurship to the black community
in a single word entrepreneurship has
meant freedom for the black community
before the Emancipation Proclamation in
1865 free blacks in the south and the
north had an insatiable appetite for
business ownership such that on the eve
of the Civil War the black collective
worth black collective wealth in the
United States was conservatively
estimated to be over 50 million dollars
for example in the 1700s James fort and
owned a manufacturing company in
Philadelphia that made sales for ships
he employed more than 40 black workers
in 1838 free black women created for
themselves and others through their
domination of the dress making the hat
making in the wig making industries in
1840 free blacks of New York also
created jobs through their ownership of
one clothes cleaners one hairdressing
salon one confectionery one fruit store
two coal yards two dry goods stores two
restaurants three tailor shops and six
boarding houses surprisingly
entrepreneurship was not limited to free
blacks slaves such as Frank McCourt John
Barry Meacham and Robert Renfro were all
were allowed to own their own businesses
they were required to share the profits
that they generated with their owners
they ultimately used their share of the
profits to buy their freedom John Barry
Meacham owned a carpentry business he
purchased the freedom of himself and his
family and twenty other friends with the
profits in 1794 Robert Renfro started a
restaurant in Nashville Tennessee with
the profits he purchased his freedom
seven years later and finally Frank
McWhorter in the early 1800s started a
company that produced saltpeter the main
ingredient in gunpowder with the
company's profits he purchased his
freedom his family's freedom and 16
other friends associated whee
his family yes my friends we have always
been business owners and I applaud and
celebrate those brave black men and
women who used entrepreneurship
literally as a tool for freedom but
before we leave the topic of the history
of black entrepreneurship I would like
to make the point that black
entrepreneurship especially during the
Jim Crow era was not loved by everyone
in fact one of the worst incidents of
violence ever visited upon blacks was
directly related to successful black
entrepreneurship this took place in
Tulsa Oklahoma On June 1st 1921 it has
been referred to as the black Holocaust
in America in the roaring 20s one of the
most affluent black communities in
America was not in New York it was not
in Chicago but it was in Tulsa Oklahoma
which was also known as the black Wall
Street fifteen thousand blacks resided
in this city and man were they something
special in a 36 square block area they
owned and operated over 600 businesses a
dollar would circulate 36 to a thousand
times sometimes taken a year to leave
the black community today unfortunately
$1 leaves the black community in 15
minutes the main thoroughfare of this 36
square block area was Greenwood Avenue
intersected by Archer and pine the first
letter in each of these street names is
G a and P which spells gap and that's my
friend where the Gap Band from Tulsa
Oklahoma got their names these brilliant
black business men and women owned 30
grocery stores 21 restaurants six
private airplanes two movie theaters one
hospital one bank and one bus system now
don't these facts just warm you with
pride and aberration
well the pride and admiration that you
me and those 15,000 black people had was
equalled by the jealousy and disdain of
the 3,000 Ku Klux Klan men who resided
in Tulsa
On June 1st 1921 the black Wall Street
in a period of 12 hours was gone the
black citizens were awakened that day by
airplanes flying low over their homes
such that homemade turpentine bombs
could be dropped instantly in blazing
the houses and when those black citizens
fled their homes they were greeted by
machine-gun fire from the Klansmen most
of whom were World War one veteran's by
the end of the day these Klansmen most
of whom were also respected citizens in
the white community these Klansmen had
burned down all of the businesses and
killed 300 black Americans no white
citizens were arrested amazingly this
type of incident was not unique to Tulsa
it happened in over a hundred other
black communities in America during the
Jim Crow era now these facts of
terrorism against black Americans has
had a devastating impact on black wealth
creation as one 90 year old black woman
said from Tulsa Oklahoma she said my
husband I own ten buildings that house
ten of our businesses she said it's a
day I own nothing I rent my friends
incidents like these combined with 200
250 years of unpaid slavery have left
black Americans economically in twenty
eight almost worse off than we were
during slavery for example the Boston
Globe did research and found that the
average net worth of a white family in
Boston is two hundred and forty-seven
thousand dollars the research showed
that the net worth for a black family in
Boston is eight dollars the black
community desperately needs the
government to help us because it was
legal government public policy that is
the foundation of this disparity in
addition our country desperately needs
more black entrepreneurs who can create
significant wealth for themselves and
others in a book titled a Millionaire
Next Door the Eider authors cite the
fact that 80
percent eighty percent of the country's
wealthiest people gang their wealth
through entrepreneurship by either being
an entrepreneur investing in
entrepreneurs or working for an
entrepreneurial firm 20 percent of the
balance of the wealthiest people in
America gain their wealth the tough
old-fashioned way
they inherited it okay is Eugene Lang
the founder of the I have a dream
foundation say it there is absolutely
nothing wrong with becoming rich as long
as one enriches others along the way and
wealthy black entrepreneurs do just that
they enrich other minorities by giving
them jobs yes like all entrepreneurs my
friend black entrepreneurs do good for
society by doing well for themselves
there was an article by Clarence page
which magnifies the need for more black
entrepreneurs and for black
entrepreneurial firms that presently
exists for those firms to grow Clarence
page cited the fact that a recent study
was shown that black males in their 20s
committed four violent crimes for every
one crime committed by white males in
the same age category but when the study
was controlled for employment there was
no significant differences in the crime
rate who are the most likely employers
of black males and other minorities
black entrepreneurs what we know is that
the largest employer of blacks in
America is the government the second
largest employer of blacks in America
are black owned companies black
entrepreneurs there was research that
show that like their ancestors black
entrepreneurs regardless of their
company's location be their company
located in the city or in the suburbs
black entrepreneurs create jobs for
minorities dr. Timothy Bates did
research and what he showed was that
white owned companies located in
minority communities have workforces
that are 32 percent minority while black
owned companies located in minority
communities have workforces that are 85
percent minority then he moved the study
out of the inner cities and he found
that white owned companies located in
white
Unity's have workforces that are 15
percent minority
conversely black owned companies in
white communities have a workforce that
is at least 75 percent minority
obviously these facts show that more
black entrepreneurs and larger black
owned companies will help solve the
problems of providing jobs for
minorities and it is indeed a problem
even a day when unemployment is four
point one percent black unemployment is
over 50 percent greater than that it's
six point eight percent in a major
cities like Chicago sixty percent of
black males between the ages of 20 to 24
are unemployed we need more black
entrepreneurs ladies and gentlemen
simply placing companies in minority
communities does not always create jobs
for minorities the company's ownership
is just as important as the company's
location for example in the Austin
community in Chicago on the west side of
Chicago the Austin community has a
population of 100,000 people during this
time of low unemployment 11 percent of
the Austin community is unemployed 23
percent receive food stamps and 98
percent are minority this same community
has one of the densest populations of
small manufacturing companies these
4,000 companies located in the Austin
community which are primarily white
owned they employ 90,000 people only 8%
of those employees are minority now it
would be too simple to blame this
entirely on racism instead the reality
is that a lot of this has to do with how
people get jobs especially in small
companies the way did they get jobs is
primarily based on employee referrals by
friends and family
the company's initial employees tend to
come from the owners same communities
because that's who the entrepreneur
knows therefore that's who gets referred
and hired for the new openings the same
phenomena surfaces with small
women-owned companies where women
employees are the prevalent are more
prevalent therefore let me repeat it
we need larger and more black owned
companies
this would benefit the black and the
minority community and the country as a
whole
America is strongest when all of its
citizens are employed in closing what
can you what can you do to support black
entrepreneurship one I encourage you to
block by products or services from black
owned companies being myself I use the
best and the brightest when I decide who
to buy products from and where to get my
services and by the way my law firm
therefore in pursuing the best and the
brightest is a black law firm by the way
when I pursued the best and the
brightest my accounting firm is a firm
owned by a black woman in any city that
I travel to in America and throughout
the world
I always try to find a black owned
restaurant so that I can find a way to
put money into black economy as soon as
I set foot in that that locale number
two I encourage institutions that you
are associated with I encourage you to
encourage those institutions to use
black professional service firms that
they should not just simply do the
stereotypical thing and hire black
people for security and hire black
people in the food services industry
that are the low margin businesses but
hire black professional services firms I
serve on the board of trustees of my
alma mater Williams College and I made
this pitch that we should be looking for
the best and the brightest to manage our
money and that best and the brightest
includes black institutions and in
response to that Williams College made
the decision to give some of our money
to to to asset management firms at our
black home one is owned by a Harvard
Business School alum Paul Viera in the
second is owned by John Rogers Arielle
Investments I serve on the board of
directors of SC Johnson wax we wait we
make Glade rain and wind X we do nine
billion dollars a year I say it the same
to them and that is we should be
accessing and using the best
the brightest and the best and the
brightest includes black people with
that we decided to hire Fairview Capital
Fairview Capital is a private equity Fon
defiance located in Connecticut with
over four billion dollars of assets
under management and the general partner
is a brilliant black woman from Howard
University by the name of Joey and price
so I encourage you to take action
relative to helping black people help
themselves by helping black people grow
their businesses that results in black
people being hired paying more taxes and
being a constructive part of America's
society and finally in closing for those
of you in this room who are of African
descent all of us all of us come from
countries that were either colonized are
put into slavery except those from
Ethiopia but all of us come from
countries where we were in bondage if
all of those of you in this room of
African descent I say to you in 50 years
all of us will be gone and when we're
gone we're gonna get a chance to meet
our slave ancestors and those ancestors
will ask us what did you do for our
people when you were free and I'm
hopeful that you'll be able to say I
supported black entrepreneurs who
created jobs for black people because
black people who have jobs are
self-sufficient and self-sufficient
people lived in healthy communities I
was a part of the solution to the
problem thank you all very much and have
a great day
[Applause]
